awd_abstract_narration: The overall goal of the proposed project is to elucidate the fundamental physical mechanisms governing the reorientation of cell migration polarity, which affects how persistently the cells maintain their directionality of movement and their ability to follow spatial cues during physiological processes such as wound healing, the immune response, and embryonic development.  The phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) signaling pathway has been implicated in the control of cell reorientation, which is achieved by stabilizing the branching of existing cell protrusions activity.  Using an approach integrating live-cell fluorescence microscopy, image analysis, and computational modeling, the team will characterize and manipulate the dynamics of signal transduction pathways, focal adhesions, and the actin cytoskeleton during protrusion branching.  The hallmarks of cell reorientation thusly identified will be re-evaluated in PI3K-inhibited cells to evaluate if the dynamics are altered and how.  These research objectives are to be integrated with educational activities, and, through the support and training of graduate students and the participation of undergraduate students, the project will contribute to the training of researchers in the cross-disciplinary areas of engineering analysis and cell biology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Mesenchymal cells such as fibroblasts play important roles in tissue homeostasis and repair. These cells move by protruding structures called lamellipodia, which compete with one another to determine the overall direction of migration. In this project, we have provided definitive evidence that F-actin bundles containing fascin-1, such as those found in filopodia (finger-like structures that protrude from the cell), govern the formation and orientation of new lamellipodia. We have shown that F-actin bundles/filopodia serve as structural templates for lamellipodia and play a role in biochemical signal transduction as well. We went on to show that modulation of fascin-1 expression tunes cell morphology and affects directed migration. Thus, we have successfully connected subcellular dynamics to macroscopic cell form and function. To help explain the subcellular dynamics we observed, we formulated and analyzed computer models that describe how adhesion, signaling, and cytoskeletal dynamics are integrated.

Broader Impacts: In addition to standard publications reporting the results summarized above, we authored two extensive methods chapters: one detailing our methods and codes for live-cell imaging and computational image analysis and the other on stochastic modeling of protrusion dynamics. In addition, a review on directed migration of mesenchymal cells was co-authored. These resources for the research community document methods and ideas primarily developed under NSF-CBET support.

This award directly supported the training of two PhD students, and it contributed thematically to teaching. In Spring 2012, a 4-lecture module on Wound Healing and Cancer was delivered, based primarily on cell migration (including research results from this project). Portions of this material were delivered again in both 2014 and 2015.
